Award.AwardTitle: Building Culturally Responsive Evaluation and Assessment Expertise at Selected HBCU Institutions (HBCU-CREA)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) supports conferences that seek to increase the research capacity of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) faculty at HBCUs. The Center for Culturally Responsive Evaluation and Assessment (CREA) at the University of Illinois at Urbana - Champaign will conduct a preconference professional development workshop and subsequent conference sessions at the 2017 CREA conference, which will directly benefit faculty and administrators at HBCUs. CREA 2017 will be held in Chicago, Illinois from September 27-29, 2017.

The professional development activities are designed to support institutional efforts to strengthen competitiveness for research and evaluation in STEM and promote related institutional capacity in broadening participation research. Selected conference participants will gain access to external evaluation expertise, support in implementing culturally and contextually relevant assessment and evaluation practices on their campuses, and be introduced to faculty and consultants interested in collaborating on future research projects. By providing professional development that builds institutional capacity and expertise within the HBCU community of researchers to conduct culturally responsive evaluations and assessments, this projects contributes significantly to the body of knowledge related to broadening participation and ensures evaluations of projects are rigorous, culturally responsive, and contextually relevant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project impact began with participant selection. Senior leaders of HBCUs were invited to nominate up to two institutional representatives to attend the preconference workshop and CREA Conference. Nominators were asked to identify institutional representatives based upon how they could influence the quality of future proposal submissions, creating important buy-in and expectations from each participating institution.

 

Selected faculty and administrators received a customized professional development preconference workshop and attended the 4th International Conference of the Center for Culturally Responsive Evaluation and Assessment (College of Education, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign). The workshop enhanced proposal development skills to improve the competitiveness of proposals submitted to NSF. The highly interactive workshop focused specifically on the incorporation of evaluative thinking and culturally responsive evaluation (CRE) as key elements in conceptualizing projects and proposals.

 

The workshop curriculum combined content on the Foundations of Culturally Responsive Evaluation (CRE) with mixed methods research and evaluation designs, preparation of logic models, matching project design to institutional context, and basic strategies of program design for evaluability. All content paid special attention to the demands of an HBCU context.  Using the “evaluation cycle” as a metaphor and organizing scheme, presenters guided participants through key strategies for developing and implementing culturally responsive interventions that would meet solicitation requirements of NSF and NIH.

 

Intellectual merit was enhanced by inclusion of basic logic modeling strategies to provide a nuanced understanding of how and under what circumstances interventions can be expected to work. This richness in project conceptualization and design is particularly important to broadening participation efforts in STEM, an area in which HBCUs have excelled in for many years. This project's stimulation of evaluation capacity building within HBCU institutions, builds better understanding of how HBCU programming has achieved enviable success in fostering the STEM careers of students of color when other institutions have not. By providing professional development that builds institutional capacity and expertise within HBCU UP grantee institutions to design and propose interventions that are culturally responsive evaluations and assessments, this project contributes significantly to the continually emerging body of knowledge on broadening participation and success of institutions in competing for funding in this vital area.

 

Additionally, the CREA conference included a special session for workshop participants to meet with members of the evaluation and assessment community interested in partnering on future project proposals. Participants in this session included representatives of the NSF INCLUDES, national technical assistance organizations, as well as several NSF program officers attending the conference. This session included informal time for participants to interact with evaluation consultants and exchange contact information after exploring mutual interests.

 

This project advances and broadens access to two decades of work in the area of CRE that enhances the conceptualization of projects. Developing this capacity has broader impacts producing better conceptualized future projects and increased understanding of institutions’ cultural and contextual issues. Application of this knowledge can improve future project designs, evaluations, and assessments across the institution and result in improved learning environments and student outcomes. The impact of stronger program development spreads across disciplines, and permeates future programs regardless of funding source. More graduates, who experience more effective and rigorous learning environments, contribute to the depth of the American workforce, particularly in STEM disciplines. Given the focus of HBCUs, this success adds necessary and beneficial diversity to the American workforce in high-tech career fields that are both high-wage and high-demand.

 

The workshop participants were faculty, staff, and administrators from: Fort Valley State University, North Carolina A&T State University, Tennessee State University, Lincoln University, Hinds Community College, Jackson State University, Stillman College, Shaw University. Participants reported that the program:

  • was structured effectively with presentations meeting their expectations,

  • reflected clear objectives presenters were engaging

  • presentations were accessible for a non-technical audience

  • produced knowledge gains in CRE evaluative thinking, reporting better understanding of the  CRE framework

  • led them to plan to incorporate CRE and culturally responsive assessment in future proposals submitted to NSF 

  • resulted in increased confidence in their ability to prepare more competitive and could improve their respective institutions' ability to develop more competitive NSF grant proposals

     Additionally, participants reported their participation in the workshop and CREA conference provided them with the critically important opportunity to “gain access to external evaluation expertise, support in implementing culturally and contextually relevant assessment and evaluation practices on their campuses, and be introduced to consultants interested in collaborating on future project proposals.”

     

 In summary, the workshop was perceived by the majority of the participants to have made a substantive contribution to their proposal development skills and perspectives while also being reported by some to be “transformative”.
